overall_feedback: I think it's wonderful. These days, the most difficult part of enjoying indie games is finding the ones I like in the first place, because there's such a vast sea of them with such a small percent being to my preferences. And it takes a long time to sift through recommendations on Steam or Itch, where most of the games aren't really to my interest. I understand that there's no way to understand or match a person's preferences perfectly, but any improvements are welcome!

feedback: They have in common that they are both narrative horror games. However, they aren't thematically, narratively or mechanically similar. As the focus of WTD is on story, I feel that the match is somewhat relevant.
overall_feedback: I think this is a great idea, and I'd love to see an AI driven recommendation system for itch.io.  I've always felt that Steam's various attempts at recommendation systems have missed something, either in the thematic content or the mood of the games. For example, a person may enjoy Rocket League because they like futuristic rocket cars, or because they like team ball-games. An algorithm might decide that because they like Rocket League, they ought to like FIFA or Madden, when acutally Wipeout might be a better recommendation, or vice versa. Another example: I don't normally like 3rd person 3D platformers, but because I've played Life is Strange and Chrono Trigger, maybe I'd appreciate Prince of Persia: Sands of Time as a recommendation, because it features time travel. However, if I mostly enjoyed those two games because I enjoyed complex, branching stories, I would appreciate the Prince of Persia recommendation.  I suppose what I am getting at is that an algorithm needs to not just try to draw similarities between games, but to analyse a players' library and habits and attempt to understand the connections between what they like and what they don't. What makes a good recommendation is different from person to person. For some it might be purely mechanical. For others it might be thematic. Or it could be a completely different reason. Attempting to make recommendations based entirely on percieved similarity cannot encompass this.   Thanks for reading this long reply!

feedback: Short and creative
overall_feedback: I don't think many AAA games have many points of contact with small (and experimental) indie games, and I don't personally think recommendations should rely exclusively on similarities. The idea of improving discoverability sounds like a good one, but I think it shouldn't necessarily be correlated to big blockbuster games. It would be a bit more fair to suggest something "that the player doesn't know yet if they might like"

feedback: Well wow, I did not expect this. As only the composer of Reclaim Earth, it's an honor to think this was thought as a similarity. I am thinking that graphic style and RPG elements is what ties it to Reclaim Earth here.
overall_feedback: I actually like this idea a lot and I really appreciate this study because the suggestions do not happen for Indie Games and if they do it's only word of mouth which is sometimes good or bad. Bad because if the game is recommended to a player that does not like it they will not play it. Good because if the game similarity recommenedation is loved by that player they will most likely give a it shot. I thought that the game recommendations were very different and a nice range in terms of styles presented. Personally, I always thought  Reclaim Earth was a hybrid of Turok meets Doom/Quake. That is how I always pitched it. I hope your research and pitch goes far and I hope to see it implemented in the future.

feedback: There are no survival mechanics in Jill.
overall_feedback: This would be a useful resource if available and great for bringing indie games to potentially new audiences, expanding their reach. However, through filling out this survey and seeing the ways I describe my games as being dissimilar to the various AAA titles, I fear that players will play the indie games recommended with the expectation that it will be similar to the AAA title they played. Many indie games tend to be smaller/shorter experiences given their limits, so players may feel lied to by the recommendations and end up having a negative experience due to their assumptions about the content of the indie games. Already there is an issue of gamers getting upset with developers because they feel that indie games "aren't worth (their) money / time" and I feel that it's a valid fear that this may cause some audiences to develop a negative relationship with independent titles.

feedback: platformer with puzzle elements, so i guess?
overall_feedback: So AAA games ask for an investment, while many indie games ask for way less. Like, if AAA games are movies, and mobile time-wasters are like daytime/reality tv shows, then indie games are produced netflix tv shows, in terms of "how much investment and engagement does this medium ask you to put forth". That isn't just a trait to put to the side while considering AAA vs indie genres and other comparisons. I think its integral to the way a lot of indie designers work and develop: less repetition, strong simple core game loops, and an attention to pick-up and put-down-ability. Genres that seem to thrive in the indie space, IMHO, are like, puzzles, short narrative experiences, and games with interesting or novel mechanics, usually just one.   So, that all in mind, a puzzler != a AAA game with puzzle elements. Right? So what about the experiences are independent of everything i just mentioned. Art style, setting, game verbs, etc. Maybe those sorts of things should be considered more when drawing comparisons.  but what the heck do i know anyway.

Like, if AAA games are movies, and mobile time-wasters are like daytime/reality tv shows, then indie games are produced netflix tv shows, in terms of "how much investment and engagement does this medium ask you to put forth". That isn't just a trait to put to the side while considering AAA vs indie genres and other comparisons. I think its integral to the way a lot of indie designers work and develop: less repetition, strong simple core game loops, and an attention to pick-up and put-down-ability. Genres that seem to thrive in the indie space, IMHO, are like, puzzles, short narrative experiences, and games with interesting or novel mechanics, usually just one.   So, that all in mind, a puzzler != a AAA game with puzzle elements. Right? So what about the experiences are independent of everything i just mentioned. Art style, setting, game verbs, etc. Maybe those sorts of things should be considered more when drawing comparisons.  but what the heck do i know anyway.

THE THIRD ONE is more of a silly visual novel than an FPS, so I don't think players of this game would really go for it.
overall_feedback: I think it's a great idea! It may be difficult because indies (especially super small indies on itch) tend to be much more niche experiences. AAA games are purposefully broad, so while a percentage of players may enjoy a related indie game, it's likely not close to being a one-to-one ratio, if that makes sense. Still, if you can make it work, even capturing that small percentage would be incredibly valuable to indies.

feedback: MAYYBEE??? But ultimately no because the focus of my game's relationship is with a bunch of old dudes and not women.
overall_feedback: I would rate things more similar based on a few factors, not limited to:  1) content / story (romance or relationship building, especially in a queer context) 2) game play (visual novel / click and choose responses, more static gameplay) 3) art style (essentially the look and feel of the artwork and characters) 4) console (PC/computer)  if at least TWO of these seem to match, I would consider recommending it as a match.  Good luck with your research! UoA is my alma mater so it was really mind boggling to receive a UoA email again.

Good luck with the project :)

feedback: likewise, the only thing the two have in common is the shooting mechanic
overall_feedback: The idea as a whole is phenomenal. Especially if used in either of the platforms (itch or steam). I was very delighted when I saw the email, and I would really like to help to extend the platform. I personally have very little experience with writing a recommending system. But I have worked with some people how have worked on a similar project, and I have also helped them with the concepts. The following lines are just my recommendations about the algorithm, based on my assumptions. And I have no means to criticize it, or, in anyways, underestimate your efforts.  My biggest advice would be to add different weights and values to each genre. For example, knowing that a game is an "action" game doesn't mean anything important. A game being an RPG game gives us a bit more info. And then, we also have genres like "rhythmic" games, which gives us an extremely specific idea about what that game might be. That is something I found a bit unbalanced in your algorithm. sincerely, Emad.

feedback: This appears to be like a virtual girlfriend game, which is pretty irrelevant to my thing.
overall_feedback: I think generally this isn't doing a terrible job. One thing that I think would help your goal is making sure recommendations don't always point to the most popular games, which is what happens on some services like steam or youtube. If you want people to discover indie games, it would be better if games could only link to games within a certain range of popularity or lower than them. That would prevent users funneling upward to the biggest games, which they would probably already know about.

First of all, thank you for including me in your research. If these are loose suggestions then I would say you have met your mark. I didn't want to sound redundant in my elaborations but many of these are only similar in that they are simulations. I apologize for not being more helpful.  In my opinion, they are all simulations and so may appear in the same category. I believe there are category filters for "simulation" in Steam and Itch. However, as for recommendations and "similar-to," they could be narrowed down more. A few of these look like management sims, which is a good subcategory that actually fits well with my in-progress game, Korrigans, but unfortunately not for Evol Pedal.  As for the suggestions, I guess some more similar ones would be more evolution focused. Something like Spore would make sense. Or some sort of aquatic life game perhaps. I'm sure those who like my game are also interested in other types of simulations, though.  I think this is a great idea for a website. Everyone I know loves indie games, and they also like supporting developers directly. Having this kind of comparison side-by-side sounds like a great way to get exposure.  I hope this helps and thanks for reaching out to me. Good luck on your thesis!  Best, Evol Games

feedback: This is more of a management simulation, whereas mine is evolution, physics, and movement based.
overall_feedback: First of all, thank you for including me in your research. If these are loose suggestions then I would say you have met your mark. I didn't want to sound redundant in my elaborations but many of these are only similar in that they are simulations. I apologize for not being more helpful.  In my opinion, they are all simulations and so may appear in the same category. I believe there are category filters for "simulation" in Steam and Itch. However, as for recommendations and "similar-to," they could be narrowed down more. A few of these look like management sims, which is a good subcategory that actually fits well with my in-progress game, Korrigans, but unfortunately not for Evol Pedal.  As for the suggestions, I guess some more similar ones would be more evolution focused. Something like Spore would make sense. Or some sort of aquatic life game perhaps. I'm sure those who like my game are also interested in other types of simulations, though.  I think this is a great idea for a website. Everyone I know loves indie games, and they also like supporting developers directly. Having this kind of comparison side-by-side sounds like a great way to get exposure.  I hope this helps and thanks for reaching out to me. Good luck on your thesis!  Best, Evol Games

overall_feedback: I am 100% in favour of any reasonable method that helps indie creators boost their discoverability! I think you will have your work cut out for you with games like mine, simply because even the most prestigious visual novels fall into a more AA space in terms of budget and audience. Closer matches might be more conventional games with dating sim elements (like Fire Emblem) or games that are effectively visual novels with added gameplay elements (like the Ace Attorney series). Anyway, I love your goal and wish you the best of luck with it!

Gladiabots is very niche and "original" so it's pretty hard to find matching games. I would recommend these ones for their programming gameplay components : https://store.steampowered.com/app/464350/Screeps/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/375820/Human_Resource_Machine/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/792100/7_Billion_Humans/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/504210/SHENZHEN_IO/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/736260/Baba_Is_You/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/619150/while_True_learn/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/716490/EXAPUNKS/  Great idea though! Indie devs like me would really benefit from this kind of tool if it could be available to a large public. Keep up the good work!

overall_feedback: The idea is good, but I don't know what data you are using to make the connections. Whatever it is, it seems like it's the wrong data! Some of these matches are about as bad as I could make even as a joke (Call of Duty is probably the joke I would make for a maximally bad match, actually). If you're doing text comparisons only I think you are disregarding some of the more fundamental match-ups. Some kind of screenshot color analysis might be good. The itch-io tags on my game are "Action-Adventure, Level Editor, pumpkins, Robots, Top Down Adventure, yeti" which really should've led to a very different set of games if you are weighting those tags heavily (I didn't even mention zombies in there, though they are prominent in the game). I'm honestly not sure of any reasonably recent (last 15 years) AAA games that bear much of any similarity to Dr. Lunatic, but Terraria is definitely much more in the ballpark. I may have the wrong game for your testing, as it's so dissimilar to things they release today.

overall_feedback: This is a great idea, I used to search for indie games similar to larger titles myself. Although this algorithm has a long way to go. It seems to me like it could recommend anything that has one or two matching tags. I'll just quickly go over 3 different games that I would expect to see as recommendations. https://store.steampowered.com/app/909970/Tech_Corp/ This one is basically about the same thing, you sell hardware in both games. https://store.steampowered.com/app/239820/Game_Dev_Tycoon/ Whereas this one has very similar gameplay and is close thematically. https://store.steampowered.com/app/621060/PC_Building_Simulator/ This one is much different, although both games revolve around hardware.

I'll just quickly go over 3 different games that I would expect to see as recommendations. https://store.steampowered.com/app/909970/Tech_Corp/ This one is basically about the same thing, you sell hardware in both games. https://store.steampowered.com/app/239820/Game_Dev_Tycoon/ Whereas this one has very similar gameplay and is close thematically. https://store.steampowered.com/app/621060/PC_Building_Simulator/ This one is much different, although both games revolve around hardware.

The idea is great!!! I would love people from Steam and playing big games to discover my game. However my game is most similar to other indie games. The matcher could use some work. My games are most similar/inspired by games by Amanita Design (Samorost, Machinarium, Botanicula), Monkey Island Series, other adventures with nature themes inside, atmospheric and musical. Here there were a couple of adventure/puzzle games so I clicked "yes" on them, however apart from the type of game, nothing else really was similar. Perhaps Karambola apart from adventure point-and-clicks, could match for example "Limbo" which is a platformer, so different type, but the atmosphere is perhaps similar (could attract similar kind of players). Or "Flower" which is different kind and platform, but relaxing and nature-related. So perhaps look into this? Thanks for the invitation!!

It's an interesting proposition, but I feel like there's a mismatch you're not taking into account. Your software has the capacity to work well for indie games which are roughly analogous to AAA genres (e.g. indie fighting games to AAA fighting games, indie puzzle games to AAA puzzle games), but the independent sphere has a large number of games which simply do not fit in the AAA genre paradigm. My own game, EXTREME MEATPUNKS FOREVER, only shares passing resemblance with one game in this given list, but it shares large amounts of DNA with other indie games, such as Kentucky Route Zero (via the dialog system), Pyre (via the story and blending of visual novel and action elements), and Night in the Woods (via mechanical maximalism). I'm unsure what the solution to this problem is, but please keep it in mind moving forward.

overall_feedback: I like the idea of it a lot, recommending indie games based on well-known titles is a good method of getting people to check them out. Though, all the choices here seem a bit hard to pin on a game like Carrie's Order Up. My assumption here is that it's based on tags and I assume that "arcade" and "action" are bringing out all of these, while Carrie's Order Up is more of a traditional top-down arcade experience. I think a better fit would be something like "PAC-MAN CHAMPIONSHIP EDITION", which I know isn't a AAA game, but it might be worth expanding the field of known games to any of them that are widely popular. You might also want to throw in some 2D pixel-based games, as Carrie's art style is like that and I could see some players being interested in games with that style? Like someone that played Shovel Knight might want to check out other retro-inspired games.  As a side note; Carrie's Order Up is on Steam as well. I figure you're keeping the scope to itch.io recommendations but it might be worth bringing it to people's attention if a game on itch.io is also on the Steam platform, as some people do prefer some of the features Steam offers.

feedback: a sim.
overall_feedback: I think you're trying to do something really interesting here. Indie games struggle greatly to get any sort of tracktion, so any help is greatly appriciated by everyone here.  But... Ignoring the indie titles that was in the list, I think these games shows more about the AAA game scene rather than your system. This is a racing game. My game is a text game with shared data between players.
overall_feedback: I think it's a good *idea.* However part of the appeal of some niche indie games is that they are highly dissimilar to the games that are made with large budgets. The platforms, budget, and mass audience size of AAA games generate totally different kinds of experiences that small teams and budgets generate, and honestly this is part of the appeal. Large budgets cannot sustain niche gameplay, because the investors in large names need to get their money back. I'm glad that people with small budgets make games, because it means they are making things that cannot be compared to AAA games. I want to play those new, unsual, totally-different games.  As a result, I do not think you can suggest indie itch games to AAA game players based on "similarity" or "relevance." I have broad tastes. I enjoy Horizon Zero Dawn and Assassin's Creed: Origins, but I also enjoy Stardew Valley and Paratopic. These are not "similar." They may have common themes--a commitment to emotionally authentic experiences, for example, or an interest in exploring difficult emotional situations. But if you ask me to pick "similar games," you will never get me comparing Paratopic to AC:O.  I think you need to qualify "similar" or "relevant." What is similar? How is relevance determined? What themes are you using to connect indie and AAA games? it cannot be base gameplay, or aesthetics, or art style, or features. So what are you comparing?? How do you know what kinds of similarities make someone like two dissimilar games? How will you see the thread that connects my enjoyment of Eidolon and Horizon Zero Dawn? How will you evaluate the quality of that connection? I don't see you eliciting it here in this survey.

But if you ask me to pick "similar games," you will never get me comparing Paratopic to AC:O.  I think you need to qualify "similar" or "relevant." What is similar? How is relevance determined? What themes are you using to connect indie and AAA games? it cannot be base gameplay, or aesthetics, or art style, or features. So what are you comparing?? How do you know what kinds of similarities make someone like two dissimilar games? How will you see the thread that connects my enjoyment of Eidolon and Horizon Zero Dawn? How will you evaluate the quality of that connection? I don't see you eliciting it here in this survey.

feedback: This is a 3D online MMO war game. My game is a text game with shared data between players.
overall_feedback: I think it's a good *idea.* However part of the appeal of some niche indie games is that they are highly dissimilar to the games that are made with large budgets. The platforms, budget, and mass audience size of AAA games generate totally different kinds of experiences that small teams and budgets generate, and honestly this is part of the appeal. Large budgets cannot sustain niche gameplay, because the investors in large names need to get their money back. I'm glad that people with small budgets make games, because it means they are making things that cannot be compared to AAA games. I want to play those new, unsual, totally-different games.  As a result, I do not think you can suggest indie itch games to AAA game players based on "similarity" or "relevance." I have broad tastes. I enjoy Horizon Zero Dawn and Assassin's Creed: Origins, but I also enjoy Stardew Valley and Paratopic. These are not "similar." They may have common themes--a commitment to emotionally authentic experiences, for example, or an interest in exploring difficult emotional situations. But if you ask me to pick "similar games," you will never get me comparing Paratopic to AC:O.  I think you need to qualify "similar" or "relevant." What is similar? How is relevance determined? What themes are you using to connect indie and AAA games? it cannot be base gameplay, or aesthetics, or art style, or features. So what are you comparing?? How do you know what kinds of similarities make someone like two dissimilar games? How will you see the thread that connects my enjoyment of Eidolon and Horizon Zero Dawn? How will you evaluate the quality of that connection? I don't see you eliciting it here in this survey.

feedback: The only similarity is, that it is a first person shooter. Otherwise very different games.
overall_feedback: I think there should be a greater focus on niche games (other popular indie games or middle market games) as AAA games are often too broad. I often see recommendations based on GTA because GTA contains so many genres, making it difficult to compare other games to it.  My game, DUGA, is a retro FPS with roguelike element. Comparing it to DOOM and Amid Evil makes sense. Otherwise, I would compare it to old DOOM, Wolfenstein 3D, Strafe, Quake, Unreal and overall games with roguelike elements (Spelunky, Binding of Isaac, Enter the Gungeon) Otherwise, this project seems very interesting!

A few of the games would be good comparisons if the player enjoyed the art style or theme of the world, and for other games maybe generally players that like shooters would be interested. The Multiplayer games presented though were generally poor comparisons and I don't think suggesting our top down single player shooter would lead to much interaction from players of those games.

overall_feedback: I support the idea and thus will focus on two points of constructive criticism:  - Distinguish titles by game and film genre, the former being FPS, RPG etc, the latter being Fantasy, Sci-Fi etc. This may aid in better targeting clearly defined player types and fans of different aesthetic/world lore styles (e.g. RPG player + Fantasy fan = Skyrim). - Find a way to group and match games by difficulty. Nailing this makes the difference whether a recommendation feels on spot or not. Try to avoid frustration.  In my opinion, our game should be found alongside similar indie titles such as Firewatch, Dear Esther or Journey. You may want to check these out for improvements.  I hope this helps, keep it up :)

feedback: absolutely nothing in common
overall_feedback: while i think improving indie discoverability in general is good, i cant say im personally convinced with your idea, at least, not if it's kept this simple. imo a big issue with "AAA" vs indie (i use quotes because a lot of the games listed here aren't AAA at all) is that smaller team sizes and whatnot lead to completely different styles of games, and i would personally worry that a system like this leads to people not realizing exactly how those differences are going to go, and being disappointed that an indie recommendation isnt going to be similar enough to the AAA game they had in mind.  that said, even if you do get it working and people are happy with suggestions, PLEASE for the love of god actually take a look at what games are being compared with what games. your algorithm compared my small sfw indie game to an 18+ game (made by rape fetishists), which was unpleasant enough for me (and like i mentioned under that game, dont associate a sfw game with a nsfw one), but imagine this happening in reverse - what if you type in an AAA game that isn't 18+, and the indie recommendations ARE 18+? especially if the person looking it up isnt an adult? that's something you need to be really careful with.  i hope im not coming off as too harsh, i know i have a lot of criticisms but it's because ive had bad experiences with this sort of algorithm not having enough supervision. if you do figure something out that resolves those issues i hope the result is something people are happy with and that it works out how you'd like!

Its very visual novel like. Not close but it has the same type of choose your own adventure like, which is what people who like this sort of games require. This is the most accurate selection of the bunch.
overall_feedback: The problem is the gap, I think. Triple AAA games seem to try and reach as many people as possible, that's the idea they are made with most of the time. Indie games, particularly in the case of Visual Novels, are for very niche publics that looks for the one specific thing. To fit one in the mold of the other is possible but complicated. It is hard to be able to get a global game out. Everyone wants to be the next Undertale in the indie scene but there is only one Undertale, every other indie is well smaller.  I think the real trick is bridge that gap, but finding out but your general audience is able to dabble to is complex. To find that niche subject is a matter of luck and specifications. Since we are selling games to an audience that knows about games and internet culture. However if its figured it out, the niche interest of the person is easy to cater to it even from coming from high tier AAA gaming.

feedback: Same as above. And this has the Star Wars license to back it up.
overall_feedback: Frankly, I don't think fans of AAA games would enjoy many of the 2D titles. They expect high production values, voice-acting and level of polish that's not possible for a small group of people to achieve. Kalaban was made by one full-time developer, and a core team of four people. I'd say there might be a correlation with 3D walking simulators, since those at least can achieve some of the visual fidelity mainstream players expect.

feedback: Non-relevant because it is a 3D game.
overall_feedback: Thank you very much for choosing our game, Of Blood and Shadows, to be part of this study! The idea behind your investigation is very useful and I believe it will improve by a lot the discoverability of indie games. I think developing a well structured search-engine would vastly expand the audience of indie games. It was a very interesting study! If I may offer some feedback regarding it: 1) It was a little bit difficult deciding on how to rate some games, because judging by just the cover and the description was not informative enough in order to build an opinion on whether the games were similar to ours or not. The most important information that was lacking sometimes from most descriptions was:  -Whether a game is a VN (visual novel), a 2D platformer, an RPG, an FPS, an MMO, etc -Whether the genre was horror, adventure, romance, action, mystery, drama, etc. So I think adding the type and the genre of a game as keywords or tags underneath the covers would be very useful! 2) I found the thumbs up/thumbs down systema bit too restrictive, as sometimes I found myself wanting to rate something inbetween. I wish I had four options, like "similar" "slightly similar" "not very relevant" "non-relevant". An example I can provide: A game is the same style as ours (i.e. a Visual Novel type game), but the genre is horror, which is not very close to ours (mostly being action and a bit of romance).  So maybe the player would like to try out other Visual Novel games because they like those types of games, but they do not enjoy horror. So rating such a game as similar to our or not is difficult. Therefore I think the distinction between game-type, and genre is very important. One player might love horror games and not care whether they are in VN, or FPS, or RPG type. And on the other hand, another player might only like 3D-RPGs and not care whether the genre is romance based, adventure, or horror.

feedback: Game is unknown to me, but I think the Fantasy genre is similar to ours.
overall_feedback: Thank you very much for choosing our game, Of Blood and Shadows, to be part of this study! The idea behind your investigation is very useful and I believe it will improve by a lot the discoverability of indie games. I think developing a well structured search-engine would vastly expand the audience of indie games. It was a very interesting study! If I may offer some feedback regarding it: 1) It was a little bit difficult deciding on how to rate some games, because judging by just the cover and the description was not informative enough in order to build an opinion on whether the games were similar to ours or not. The most important information that was lacking sometimes from most descriptions was:  -Whether a game is a VN (visual novel), a 2D platformer, an RPG, an FPS, an MMO, etc -Whether the genre was horror, adventure, romance, action, mystery, drama, etc. So I think adding the type and the genre of a game as keywords or tags underneath the covers would be very useful! 2) I found the thumbs up/thumbs down systema bit too restrictive, as sometimes I found myself wanting to rate something inbetween. I wish I had four options, like "similar" "slightly similar" "not very relevant" "non-relevant". An example I can provide: A game is the same style as ours (i.e. a Visual Novel type game), but the genre is horror, which is not very close to ours (mostly being action and a bit of romance).  So maybe the player would like to try out other Visual Novel games because they like those types of games, but they do not enjoy horror. So rating such a game as similar to our or not is difficult. Therefore I think the distinction between game-type, and genre is very important. One player might love horror games and not care whether they are in VN, or FPS, or RPG type. And on the other hand, another player might only like 3D-RPGs and not care whether the genre is romance based, adventure, or horror.

overall_feedback: I love this idea if it can work in practice. I worry that too many players of AAA games think more in genres and less about the kind of experience they want which is where I'd settle indie games more. I wonder if there's some way to translate into a more nuanced search?

I would recommend taking game genre into account. Players tend to stick to their 'genre' of choice a lot of times. (RPG players might not play Adventure Games, Visual Novel players may play RPGS but not FPS type games and so on.) VNs are a niche and if compared to other genres would be better compared to games like Dragon Age, Origins of Divinity (because romance routes), or the old Telltale games (which are essentially visual novels themselves). Post-Apocalyptic fans might be interested in As We Know It, but since visual novels are such a niche I am unsure if they would try it due to the genre.

feedback: Same as earlier : While color palette is similar and the focus is on a narrative-driven experience, TWD is much more focused on social choice than Please, since the latter is a lonely and very linear affair.
overall_feedback: Some indie games might be able to bridge the gap between AAA and Indie, such as more mechanics-oriented action titles, but most micro-indie games I know and love and play are so far removed from what a mainstream gamer might consider a game that recommendations might be tricky to do. There is a intrinsic mistrust for "walking simulators" that action-oriented gamers might never be able to overcome, I'm afraid. Micro-indie games might need to reference each other in recommendations for any of us small devs to have a chance.

feedback: Although Danganronpa's narrative thrives on despair, it is at its core a very pop and positive story. It is also a very long visual novel. Unlike the very short walking-simulator style of Please.

feedback: Almost a thumbs down, since I am unsure players interested in Death Stranding would enjoy Please. Although both are lonely, desperate experiences with open-ended narratives, I don't think comparing it to the much discussed Death Stranding is managing player expectations in a positive way : they might end up expecting much more from the 10 minutes, mechanically simple experience of Please.

feedback: As stated above : Shape On The Ground is a psychological introspection walking sim. Although there are aspects of psychological introspection to be found in TWD titles and their social decision making mechanics, it is also embedded  in horror themes, which are somewhat softened in Shape On The Ground. Unsure if a player who enjoyed TWD will find anything clear to enjoy from my game in comparison.
overall_feedback: Not to make it look like my game is pretentiously too 'out there' for any other AAA game to be recommended from, but The Shape On The Ground is an interesting choice since it is very different from anything AAA titles usually want to accomplish. The only similar experiences I've seen were coming from the indie circles (Perfection, The Survey, etc.), so this one is a tough nut to crack.

feedback: This is an investigative character-driven visual novel. Players coming off of this title will find little to love in the lonely, free-form, open-themed Shape On The Ground.
overall_feedback: Not to make it look like my game is pretentiously too 'out there' for any other AAA game to be recommended from, but The Shape On The Ground is an interesting choice since it is very different from anything AAA titles usually want to accomplish. overall_feedback: I think this is a great idea but it is pretty difficult to find matches for some games that do things you just don't see in AAA games often (or in some cases, ever). So you have to think about what it is the fans of a game like most about it. One fantasy game might be popular because it's brutal and realistic, another might be popular because it's light and fun. TDLF is a mental health story dressed in fairy tale trappings. Good luck finding multiple AAA titles to match it to, lol.  Seriously though, good luck! I hope your project goes well; I would totally use this recommendation engine, accurate or no. :)

Sex game... story is tangential.
Visual novel/otome, good recommendation.

The audience for Cyberpunk 2077 would be annoyed at the recommendation of my game because there is not enough violence and a dearth of 'cold hard killer' vibe.

Although story is not the main focus, the atmosphere and art emphasis, and that it's not selling itself as a 'difficult' platformer makes it a possibly appropriate recommendation. One segment of visual novel / story game players is looking for more accessible games that are low key.
Tactical RPG... no special emphasis on story as far as I can tell.
Puzzles in a realistic environment from first person is very unlike Scrambled.

overall_feedback: The problem with this is that you're comparing indie games to AAA games. If you're trying to improve discoverability of indie games, you should compare my indie game to other indie games to promote them via the recommendation system. My game is a lot like Borderlands - but being an indie game, it of course doesn't have the scope or polish that borderlands does. So if I'd already played borderlands, I might want to play Black Ice, but if not, I might choose to play Borderlands instead, which would hurt the indie game.

Totally depends on the algorithm's weighting factors. As a concept it has obvious merits but for indies to take advantage of it they need to be able to 'game' it in the sense of providing the algorithm the right information in the right place.  Seems like the keyword here is 'body'; whereas my project takes place internally within a person, the algorithm has structured this around external body horror and objectification.

I think our scope is too small to be compared to a game like this
overall_feedback: I think this is a really interesting idea. I think one issue in comparing small games on itch to AAA titles on steam is that the scope of games is often so different that players used to AAA scope may be disappointed in the scope of small independent games. Something that takes into account the game length/average playtimes, as well as the scope of mechanics, may help in preventing this type of disappointment when making recommendations

feedback: While both have puzzle elements, this one is more oriented towards who like open world exploration with enemies and a story.
overall_feedback: The idea of this system is already great and will probably help alot. I also think it would be nice to have system that can translate description supplied by players in a natural language to queries that can filter games by features more elaborate than tags such as game mechanics, art style, etc. It could rely to gameplay videos (or trailers) to collect the needed information to index games. I usually find myself having a hard time searching for games that fit my desires even using the usual tag systems or text queries.

feedback: Do not match at all. The prediction was propably based on both games beeing tagged as "action".
overall_feedback: The matches seem to be mainly chosen based on the fact that Pixelstorm is tagged as action. The problem is that the games are still fundamentally different, both gameplay- and style-wise. I would suggest putting more weight on the other tags because they define the game more closely. For example, is Pixelstorm tagged with "2D" and "arcade", and they're still where games like halflife.
